useCaseName: PATHS (Process for Academic Transformation through Human-centric Systems)
name: Erin Sicuranza
description:
UD PATHS introduce a transformative approach to managing and utilizing academic knowledge by integrating AI, human oversight, and advanced Knowledge Graphs.

See https://udel.flintbox.com/technologies/532e930b-f029-4918-9f27-6944abecedba
tools:
UD PATHS introduce a transformative approach to managing and utilizing academic knowledge by integrating AI, human oversight, and advanced Knowledge Graphs (KGs). This system leverages AI and custom pipelines to ingest and operationalize academic content, enabling institutions to navigate and apply their knowledge ecosystems. UD PATHS tackles several key challenges in higher education by focusing on enhancing contextual understanding, fostering collaboration, optimizing resources, building adaptive curricula, and ensuring transparency in AI. 

Primary tools used: AWS Bedrock, Claude, Neo4j, custom programming for data ingestion, human approval process, knowledge graph storage, prompt repository and data output.
users:
Academic institutions who want to leverage their own internal academic data. At UD, we are currently partnering with faculty, academic program managers, department chairs, and cross-institutional research collaborators in the state of Delaware.

This data processing solution allows technical professionals to develop custom applications like UD Study AiDE (see next use case), federated learning projects, and more, using data that becomes structured, human-verified, and readable by humans and machines.

name: Erin Sicuranza
description:
UD StudyAide is a tool that uses UD25-21 PATHS to transform academic materials, such as lecture transcripts and PowerPoint presentations, into structured and verified study materials.

https://udel.flintbox.com/technologies/b6650a58-19f4-4a14-8b7c-a680ca1b3cbc
https://pathsengine.udel.edu/
tools: UD StudyAiDE with Study Sessions (UD StudyAiDE) is powered by a custom created innovation called PATHS (Process for Academic Transformation through Human-centric Systems). PATHS is an approach to managing and utilizing academic knowledge by integrating AI, human oversight, and advanced Knowledge Graphs. In addition to the tools used by PATHS, UD Study AiDE relied on custom developed UX/UI.
users: Faculty can create tailored learning materials that align with their teaching styles. For Students, the platform offers study sessions that provide insights into individual, bespoke learning metrics, with AI support to interpret and optimize their study practices.

name: Jared Reimer
description: Agentic AI for all members of the UW community
tools: Azure AI Foundry, cloudforce nebulaONE, OpenAI GPT-4.1 / GPT-5
users: All of UW (except possibly UW Medicine TBD)

useCaseName: Claude Code Enterprise Deployment with Portkey
name: Michael Vaughn
description: We're considering whether to leverage Portkey (or another LLM gateway) to standardize on a coding solution for central IT, perhaps Claude Code, leveraging models from our existing cloud providers.
users: Developers and other technologists in central IT or the extended IT family at Yale.

name: Jake Halsey
description: We have a queue of accounts receivables that await manual claiming by departments to be able to reconcile them in our system. We are looking at AI and automation processes to identify the likely claimants through both historical analysis and extracted data analysis.
tools: Python, Chroma Regex, and Ollma/Qwen are all used. The are combined in a pipeline that attempts to extract contact details through the application of existing python libraries for phone number extraction, regex for email address extraction, and LLM calls for name extraction. Semantic analysis to is run using Chromadb compare the current transaction against past transactions. We look up the likely contacts in LDAP and use their affiliation data to match the extracted contact details to real users and assess the confidence level of the match based on the source of the data and the attributes of the users. We're in the process of building a PHP front end that will allow finance users to assess the potential matches and send a notification message to any or all of them with instructions to claim the funds. We are currently in a proof of concept/prototyping phase, but our hope is to extend it with rules and additional data sources to eventually automate the high confidence notifications.
users: The finance team will use this to reduce the time funds sit in the unclaimed funds queue by proactively notifying users rather than waiting for them to search the queue for their funds.

name: Jake Halsey
description: We've identified duplicate invoices being submitted, such as inv123 being duplicated as 123_1 or 123b. This is likely due to delays in invoice processing but can result in double payments if not detected. We're currently exploring AI and Automation tools to reduce the burden of manual review.
tools:
Python, N8N, MCP, ChromaDB, Fuzzy search. I've built a python deduplication server that uses a bucketing to speed up fuzzy searching large data sets. This works well, but due to sequential invoice numbers and batch submissions of invoices, can trigger thousands of false positives that need to be reviewed manually. We've adopted 3 strategies to alleviate this: 1) Refinement, a threshold-based system that kicks off when a chain of duplicates grows too large, indicating a long running sequence or batch and applies stricter matching levels. 2) Semantic Break requirement: we use Chromadb to do a semantic comparison and reject matches below a given threshold, 3)LLM based review: We pass the final results to qwen running on our ollama server to do an automated review of the surviving matches, identifying likely true matches, and false positives. This also allows us to handle close matches between unrelated vendors and close matches between known subsidiaries or dbas. We are still in the prototyping phase using manual submissions to test and validate the system. The final component will be hooking our financial systems into a pipeline to run the job automatically and forward the results to our finance team for auditing.

All of the duplication server logic is purposely kept generic with thresholds and llm rules being passed as a parameter. The fields are categorized using an llm, and the results are used by the deduplication server to determine the best parameters for composite key generation in the bucketing process. This means the job could easily be rebuilt to do other duplication detection, such as duplicate service ticket submissions by copying the N8N pipeline and making minor configuration changes. We've built an MCP server to allow monitoring the server and even running smaller duplicate detection jobs directly from Claude code for rapid prototyping.
users: Auditors on the finance team can use this to quickly identify potential duplicates, using the final LLM based review to assist in prioritizing matches.

name: Jake Halsey
description: An agentic chat interface that can query a user's current access, identify the membership needed for the desired access and the administrator responsible for maintaining that access.
tools:
Most role-based access at UChicago is subject to a system called grouper, in which admins create and manage both static and compound groups. It greatly simplifies managing access to individual applications and if setup correctly, can automatically remove access to systems when people leave the organization. It has a well-documented API. The Challenge is that users and service desk technicians assisting them are not aware of the thousands of groups that exist, which are needed for a particular application, or which users have administrator access to add or remove them.

A RAG agent might have helped with answering some of their questions, but a better solution would be an agentic agent that can query grouper for the access needed, and the user's current access, identify gaps, the administrators they need to contact to address the gap, and return clear and concise instructions for them. 

Because the api is well documented, our identity management team was able to use claude code to generate an mcp server and get it working with Google Agent Space as a part of a case-study to review Agent Space.
users: It can be used by the service desk to determine who to forward access requests to, it can also be used by our risk team to audit access levels.

name: Stephanie Obodda
description: A web app that provides fast and accurate audio transcription through open-source and enterprise-level models, including the OpenAI Whisper model and Google Gemini. 20 hour daily limit per user.
tools: Deployed on GCP with additional APIs and services provided by Microsoft Azure.
users: Mostly researchers / faculty

description: Still under development, but we are developing a proof of concept that uses AI and machine learning to dynamically generate a multi-year degree plan based on a studentâ€™s academic and career interest, major and minor selections, completed credits, and full time / part time student status. The tool will support advisors working with students to generate personalized plans that optimize time to degree.

name: Msty Andrade
description: I would like AI to start to help users with the easier questions that are sent to the help desk. Allow users to self-serve with the help of AI. This could be from telling them the answer to taking actions in systems to complete whatever task is needed. This should free time to allow the help desk humans focus on the more tangible tasks.
users: Faculty,, Staff, Students

name: Jeanine Kleba
description: The goal is to detect fraud within a large volume of monthly P-Card (Payment Card) data, which is present in our Snowflake DW.  Today, it is a manual effort to examine, classify, and consolidate P-Card transactions, with follow-up on any suspicious transactions.  This use case aims to automate the classification and summarization effort and then utilize Snowflake Intelligence's built-in data anomaly detection algorithms to help pinpoint potential fraud.  From there, we bring humans into the loop by providing an agent for end users to interact with the data.
users: Division of Finance procurement staff

name: Antonio Nava
description: Chatbot with general search features, but it almost always asks clarifying questions BEFORE providing a response.  This is to adjust for poor prompting, and to increase the accuracy of the responses provided.  This is intended to build more confidence in the abilities of the tools.  Also, at the end of the conversation, the tool will provide an example of a single-shot prompt that the user can use for similar searches in the future.
users: Just me and a handful of AI champions

name: Antonio Nava
description: Provide training resources for a new software implementation.  This would provide support for new users as a supplement to the formal training workshops.  We have also used NotebookLM and other tools to develop the training plans, slides, practice guides, communications, and frameworks for governance.
users: Change management team that owns the software.

name: Antonio Nava
description: Groups are provided survey data, from which many pieces of information can be derived and action can be taken.  By reviewing the process steps, we identified several steps that can be supported by different prompts, then staggered them for an "almost" automated workflow.  The "almost" allows users to adjust the prompts along the way for minor adjustments that may be appropriate for their needs.  User uploads data and the system prompting serves as the mentor role, first by providing a quick summary of the available data.  Then the users loads a series of prompts within the same discussion to explore opportunities, possible response actions, personas to test the ideas, action items and timelines, and communication templates for moving forward.
users: Anyone who receives post-event surveys (the mentor goals and thems may be adjusted for the survey and audience types)

name: Antonio Nava
description: Loaded project summaries from LSS initiatives and system prompted the tool to serve as a mentor.  Users can ask about related projects and the tool will provide Lean focused resources and feedback.  The goal is to develop change agents, and also to ensure that people are not trying to solve the same problem over and over.  If someone else has had a similar challenge, this allows a channel for folks to learn more and to connect with those specific project owners.
users: Lean practitioners - or anyone interested in process improvement

name: Antonio Nava
description: Some users are used to buttons and dropdowns, so can we use that mindset to help them learn about prompt engineering?  We created a proof of concept within Excel that would allow a user to choose from dropdowns, then a concatenate formula would provide two outputs.  One could be pasted into AI which would provide a single prompt and then the AI would attempt to provide the response.  The second, when pasted into an AI, would provide several examples of prompts for the user to select from.  This idea was super rough and didn't get implemented, but I still believe there are users for whom this would be helpful.  I envision this with a web interface or within an app (maybe even within the AI UI) with additional button options or switches for an intuitive or familiar feel.  I will provide the link.  You will need to download the file to interact with the fields.  Please let me know if you find this useful and especially if you take the idea any further along.  THANK YOU!  https://ucsdcloud-my.sharepoint.com/:x:/g/personal/a1nava_ucsd_edu/ETLHs0yQpGdHtr0VTMWYws0B0tcra2RhHN7Wy0hxEEPvlQ?e=eAedBV
users: Users who are unfamiliar with AI and hesitant about prompt engineering.

Gemini can generate and iterate the code, cutting development time down to minutes. Gemini can also walk users through the processes of creating and deploying the project.

description: We get monthly reports (.csv or .xlsx)  from multiple sources that reference the names of institutions who participate in various NET+ programs. There is no consistency to how they name schools (e.g., New York University, NYU, NY University). This messes up our reporting tools, creating redundant records. We have a source of truth for our standard names, and are building a tool to "correct" the reports before we import them but resetting the names against the source of truth.
users: Managers of the various NET+ programs as each is responsible for reviewing their reports and the integrity of their data.
